unit_learning_outcomes.description: Model dependence and extreme events by copulas and extreme value theory.
Apply time series models to financial and economic variables.
Construct risk models with frequency and severity distributions.
Model insurance claims using loss distributions.
Use premium principles to price insurance products.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Preparation for lectures, tutorials and various assessment items.

assessments.description: The final examination will be a three-hour written paper with ten minutes reading time, to be held during the University Examination period.
The test will be approximately 90 minutes, to be held during class time.
There are two individual written assignments on problem solving using R.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.subject_search_title: ACST3060 - Quantitative Methods for Risk Analysis

academic_org.value: Department of Actuarial Studies and Business Analytics

data.description: This unit explores the use of statistical models in insurance: loss distributions with and without risk sharing, compound distributions and their applications in risk modelling, introduction to copulas, extreme value theory. The concepts underlying time series models and actuarial applications of time series models are also studied. Students gaining a weighted average of credit across all of ACST3058, ACST3060 and the CS2-related components of the assessment in ACST3059 (minimum mark of 60% on all three components) will satisfy the requirements for exemption from the professional subject CS2 of the Actuaries Institute.
data.search_title: ACST3060 - Quantitative Methods for Risk Analysis
